text:
- You must be exhausted.
I've been watching you.

Like, you've been
all over the place.

- I'm happy to do it, girl!
- Yeah. Yeah, girl.

'Cause you're talking about
this amazing docuseries
that is--it's so--it's so good.
I texted you after I saw it.

- I texted you
about six months ago.

- What?
[audience laughter]

- We spent a long time
in a conversation
at Jen and, I don't know--

Justin Aniston and
Jen Theroux's wedding.
And we had a long conversation.
We had a beautiful conversation

about your relationship
with Portia.

And in the morning
I sent you a nice text--

what I thought was very nice--
reached out,

and then I never
heard back from you,

like for six months, saying how
nice it was talking to you,

and I just thought,
"Screw her."
[audience laughter]

- I don't know if I got it,
or I think--

- You change your numbers
around a lot.

You got a lot of fancy footwork
going with your phone numbers.

- I do change my number a lot.
But I thought I wrote you back,

'cause I remember that long
conversation at the wedding.

- Yeah.
- Yeah.

There was alcohol
at that wedding.

- I--yeah, but I'm okay.
I remember every conversation

whether I've had
18 drinks or none,

because I'm always intoxicated
to some degree.

- Really?
- Yeah, so it's just--

People are like,
"How do you remember that?"

'Cause that's how
I am all the time.

I remember things that people
don't think I remember.

- Are you drunk right now?
- No, I'm actually very sober.

- Do you want--
you look angry about it.
[audience laughter]
- Don't know how this happened.

- Why are you sober?
You should--

This is the time
to start drinking.
- I'm a professional.

I know you don't want me
to show up here drunk.

- You can do whatever--
- I would never do that.

- Well, you were drunk on
the series that you did.

Let's talk--let's talk about
the docuseries.
Okay, so, it's on Netflix,

and it's four different
subjects,

and tell everybody
what the subjects are.

- Marriage, racism,
Silicon Valley and drugs.
- And I learned, also like you,

it's "Silicon,"
not "Silicone."

- Yeah.
- Silicon Valley.

I was saying it wrong.
He's like--

This guy in Silicon Valley was
like, "You're saying it--
That's a breast augmentation."

And I'm like,
"No, I know what that is."

He goes, "Yeah, but these are
two different things."
I'm like, "Oh, I thought that's

where 'Silicone' Valley
came from."

Was like--
[audience laughter]

Like the silicone
they put in boobs.
And he's like, "No, not at all.

There's no connection
whatsoever."

- Well, I didn't think that,
but I did think

it was pronounced "silicone,"
but anyway.

It's really, really funny,
and really informative,

as I texted you the other night,
and said how much I liked it.

You're so clever.
You're so quick with everybody.
And you really are genuinely

delving into
these subject matters

with genuine interest, and we
all learn something from it.

Like the marriage thing,
I learned

that you may want
to get married now.

- Well, now that I've--
now that I've got past the point

where everyone wants you to get
married, when you're 20 and 30,

and like, every guy you date,
they're like,

"Are you gonna marry him?
Are you gonna marry him?"

I'm like, "I hope not.
I hope I don't marry this guy."

And now that I'm past the age
and that I turned 40,

and nobody's asking me
to get married,
now I'm open to it.

- I see.
[audience laughter]

- Now that I have no viable,
like, prospects.
I'm not dating anybody.

Now I could actually
see myself doing it.

just as like, kind of like,
"Yeah, look at me now,
rebel without a cause."
[audience laughter]

- Is it that you want
what you can't have?

Like, when you had all
these opportunities,

and now you're thinking,
"Now I want it
because I don't have it."

- No, I think I'm going to
do it out of rebellion.

I don't like when anybody tells
me to conform to any idea.

So the idea of getting married
to me, it's just so--

it's too predictable,
so I wanted to not do it,

and now that I've aced that,
I'd like to maybe do it.

- Because it's not
predictable at all,

because nobody would
think you'd get married.

You have--I know a few of
the guys that you've dated,

and they're, like,
very different.

Is there something that they
all kind of have in common?
Like, what's your type?
- I don't think I have a type.

Obviously, with my history,
I don't have a type,
but I love--I do love men.

I mean, I really like them
a lot.

- Oh, I know.
[audience laughter]

- And I like--you know, just
there are so many out there,

I mean, and there are
so many to sample.

That's why I never want
to get pigeonholed.
[audience laughter]

There are just so many
possibilities.

Do you know what I'm saying?
- I do.
[cheers and applause]

But I really enjoy them.
I'm going on a date tonight.

I'm going on a date.
- And do you--

- With a man.
[audience cheers]

And listen to this:
I am growing up,

because he was--I never let
people come to my house,

or if I don't know them, I don't
want anybody picking me up,

'cause it's awkward--
then they have to drop me off,

and what if I don't want
to kiss them good night,

or sleep with them,
and then, so--
[audience laughter]

This guy says,
"I want to come pick you up

like, you know,
a real man picks up a woman,"

and I said, "You know what?
You can pick me up at my house."

So he's picking me up
at my house,

and I'm going on a date
like a real grown-up.

- Where'd you meet him?
- Online.

No, just kidding.
[audience laughter]
[audience laughter]

- That's really--
- I met him at the wedding.
No.

I met--it's some friends
setting us up.

I haven't met him yet.
- Oh, you haven't met him.

It's a blind date.
- Haven't met him, no.

But I know him.
- Oh, you do know who he is.

- I know of him.
- Is he in this business?

- He's in an extension
of this business, yes.

- 'Cause you dated an executive
before in this business.

- Yes.
- Is he that kind of guy?

- No, no, no, no.
You know him.
I'll tell you who he is.

If things get successful,
then I'll say,

"This is where I announced
our relationship
before it even started."

What a beautiful love story.
- Yeah.
[audience laughter]

- We're back
with Chelsea Handler.

and she has
a new Netflix docuseries
called "Chelsea Does,"

and one of the other topics
is drugs,

and you are very honest
about--that you do drugs,

that you like drugs,
that you drink a lot,

and you actually mixed--
you drank and took Ambien.

- I did.
What I wanted to do--

I didn't want to glorify
drug use,

because obviously people have
serious problems with drugs,

and they don't have strong
relationships

like I do with them,
and so you can--
[audience laughter]

You can get into
a tricky situation,

so you have to be very careful,
so I wanted to--

And people are very
irresponsible,

like they combine Ambien
and alcohol,

so I just wanted to kind of
do that, medically supervised,

to show people what happens
and how you behave,

and what you look like when
you are combining those things,

Like, we did Adderall.
We had a pot-infused dinner,
which was so much fun.
I mean, it was so much fun.

I woke up and I could not
open my eye the next day.

I mean, I was still stoned,
because every meal,

every course, they infused
marijuana in it,

and you're just--
by the end of the dinner,

you don't know which--I didn't
know from where my house was.

I was in it--I'm like,
"Where are the stairs?"

And I woke up and literally,
my eye was like glued shut.

And then--and then we went to
Peru and did ayahuasca,

which was amazing,
and it's supposed to be

this transcendent--do you guys
know what ayahuasca is?

It's, um--
[catcalls]

Oh, great.
[audience laughter]

It's this kind of,
like, root that people do.

They brew it,
and you have a shaman

who, like, yells at you in
Spanish while you're doing it.

And you hallucinate,
and it's supposed to be very--
- But wait, you drink it,

and then the first thing
you do is throw up.

- Vomit, yeah,
that's also on camera.

And yeah, it's--it's--
and then--

Then you had a bad
experience with it.

Oh, you didn't actually have
an experience with it

the first night,
and then you did it--

- I have a very strong
tolerance, as we've discussed.
I have a very high tolerance,

so it did not
hit me the first night.

The second night,
I went back for more--

- Is that okay to do
two nights in a row?

- I'm not sure,
but I went back,

and I said,
"I came all the way down here,

I want to do it--I want to show
people what it is,"
you know, and it was amazing,

and I had all
these beautiful imageries

of, like, your childhood, and
me and my sister laughing

on, like a kayak, and
all these beautiful things

with me and my sister and it was
just about loving my sister more

and being more accepting,
don't be so hard on her

because she doesn't really
like to travel,

or like, you know,
as much as I do,

so I kind of always--
so it was very much about,

like, opening my mind
to loving my sister,

and I thought, "Okay,
this is gonna be great,"

and then I saw my sister
like two weeks later.

I'm showing her a lot of love.
We're in Spain on holiday.
I'm like, "I love you so much."

She's like,
"You're acting so funny."

I'm like, "I love you!"
And then we were leaving,

and I put money down, you know,
on the coffee table.

My sister goes--for the cleaning
lady, you know, at the hotel.

My sister goes
to pick up the money.
And I go, "What are you doing?"

And she goes, "What?
You left this money here."

I go, "No, that's for
the cleaning lady."

And she goes, "Oh, is that
a European thing?"

I go, "No, that's
an American thing!

Now you're driving me
crazy again!"

I'm like, "You just drove me--
I was trying to be nice to you,

and you're a maniac
and you're a nightmare."

So that went out the window,
two weeks later.

- So now you have to do
ayahuasca again.
- Now I have to do it again.

Bring my sister
and have her do it, yeah.

- Again. Another thing,
you're very free with your body.

You're not ashamed of it at all.
- What?

- There's a picture of you
on a camel, just topless.

- That was on a very important
trip to Israel.

- Right.
- That I took.

- So you thought,
you're in Israel,

you should be topless
on a camel.

- Well, in
my racist documentary,

I--racist.
My racism documentary.
I interview Simone Peres,

who is the former
prime minister of Israel,

and I didn't--when I do things
that are that serious,

I have to balance them out
with something like a camel.

- I see.
[audience laughter]

- You know how it is.
I don't want people to think

I'm starting to
take myself too seriously,

so I always have to keep it,
like, on the regular.

I want you to know
I'm like a regular person.
I don't really think of myself--

Like, I'm not trying to turn
into Diane Sawyer or something.

- Right, right.
No, but you're--

I think you have
a great balance,

'cause I think you are
a really great interviewer,

'cause you ask the questions
that most people wouldn't ask,

and you're not afraid of
the way you look.

You just will expose yourself
in any kind of way

for the--for the intent of
whatever the conversation is,

and I think that
that's really cool.

- Thank you. Thank you.
- You're welcome.
